update.description:
For fun I tried bumping the version of gazebo to 1, and ran into some compile problems.

This PR should resolve the compile issues, however there is a run-time problem. All of our SDF files utilize version numbers when loading plugins. For example:

```
    <plugin
      filename="libignition-gazebo0-physics-system.so"
      name="ignition::gazebo::systems::v0::Physics">
    </plugin>
```

I have two questions:

1. Do we need a version number for both the library (e.g. the zero in `libignition-gazebo0-physics-system.so`) and in the interface (e.g. the `v0` in `ignition::gazebo::systems::v0::Physics`)? If not, can we get away with just the library version number? 

2. We can save this for Blueprint, but do we want to cmake-configure all of our SDF files to insert the current project major number? There are example and test SDF files to consider.

# Commits

1. 81e7645 : Alters the `kDefaultWorld` variable so that it's constructed using version information.
2. f40c64b : Ran `sed` to fix all the SDF files.
3.  71c1699 : Version the GUI library
4. e162e00 : Initial compile time only fix.
update.title: Working on a version issue

content.raw: That won't work (or shouldn't) because the examples are not directly part of the main CMake build. Another way to look at this is from the end-user's point of view. They should find this cmake as an example they can use in their own project.
content.html: That won't work (or shouldn't) because the examples are not directly part of the main CMake build. Another way to look at this is from the end-user's point of view. They should find this cmake as an example they can use in their own project.

content.raw: Left a minor comment about CMakeLists.txt files in the examples. Otherwise LGTM!
content.html: Left a minor comment about CMakeLists.txt files in the examples. Otherwise LGTM!

content.raw: Do we want to use `ignition-gazebo${PROJECT_VERSION_MAJOR}` here so that the we don't have to change this manually when updating versions?
content.html: Do we want to use ignition-gazebo${PROJECT_VERSION_MAJOR} here so that the we don't have to change this manually when updating versions?

That should be possible. I'll make that change.

content.raw: This sounds like a good option. What do you think @chapulina  and @azeey ?
content.html: This sounds like a good option. What do you think @chapulina and @azeey ?

I’ll go ahead and also note that you can make this work with zero maintenance by doing:

namesapce ignition {
namespace gazebo {
namespace systems {
inline namespace IGNITION_GAZEBO_VERSION_NAMESPACE {

IGNITION_ADD_PLUGIN_ALIAS(iPhysics, "ignition::gazebo::system::Physics", "Physics System", "physics")

} // namespace IGNITION_GAZEBO_VERSION_NAMESPACE
} // namespace systems
} // namespace gazebo
} // namespace ignition

That way the aliases will automatically be carried over into future versions of the plugin without needing to change any code.

content.raw:
An alternative solution to this is to use `ign-plugin` **aliases**. You can give plugins alias names, e.g. by putting this in your code:

```
IGNITION_ADD_PLUGIN_ALIAS(ignition::gazebo::systems::v0::Physics, "ignition::gazebo::systems::Physics");
```

You could even use the alias `"Physics System"` if you wanted to; there are \(virtually\) no restrictions on alias names. The only thing to note is that if any two plugins are loaded that share an alias, then that alias can no longer be used to load either of them, and then you need to either use an alias that’s unique to the plugin that you want, or you need to use the exact \(demangled\) type name of the plugin that you want. Also if a plugin has an alias that matches the type name of another plugin that’s loaded, then using that string will load the plugin that has it as a type name and ignore the one that has it as an alias.
content.html:
An alternative solution to this is to use ign-plugin aliases. You can give plugins alias names, e.g. by putting this in your code:

IGNITION_ADD_PLUGIN_ALIAS(ignition::gazebo::systems::v0::Physics, "ignition::gazebo::systems::Physics");

You could even use the alias "Physics System" if you wanted to; there are (virtually) no restrictions on alias names. The only thing to note is that if any two plugins are loaded that share an alias, then that alias can no longer be used to load either of them, and then you need to either use an alias that’s unique to the plugin that you want, or you need to use the exact (demangled) type name of the plugin that you want. Also if a plugin has an alias that matches the type name of another plugin that’s loaded, then using that string will load the plugin that has it as a type name and ignore the one that has it as an alias.

content.raw: Yup, only systems
content.html: Yup, only systems

content.raw: Sounds good to me as well. We're only removing them from systems right?
content.html: Sounds good to me as well. We're only removing them from systems right?

content.raw: That all sounds good. I assume we would want to keep the library version and ditch the interface version? If that's the case, then @azeey you might want to just remove the inline namespace for systems instead of moving them.
content.html: That all sounds good. I assume we would want to keep the library version and ditch the interface version? If that's the case, then @azeey you might want to just remove the inline namespace for systems instead of moving them.

content.raw:
> Otherwise, if we remove the inline namespace from the systems themselves, the question is whether we expect users to be linking against the same system, but of different versions, at the same time.

I think that this would be unlikely. I can’t really think of a scenario where this would play out.

> but do we want to cmake-configure all of our SDF files to insert the current project major number

I’m not really enthusiastic about this, because now you _have_ to build before you have any valid SDF files, vs being able to just `wget` and go.  Maybe that’s not a typical use case, but it’s something I do if I want to quickly check a file that’s on another branch, etc.
content.html:
Otherwise, if we remove the inline namespace from the systems themselves, the question is whether we expect users to be linking against the same system, but of different versions, at the same time.

I think that this would be unlikely. I can’t really think of a scenario where this would play out.

but do we want to cmake-configure all of our SDF files to insert the current project major number

I’m not really enthusiastic about this, because now you have to build before you have any valid SDF files, vs being able to just wget and go. Maybe that’s not a typical use case, but it’s something I do if I want to quickly check a file that’s on another branch, etc.

content.raw:
> Do we need a version number for both the library (e.g. the zero in libignition-gazebo0-physics-system.so) and in the interface (e.g. the v0 in ignition::gazebo::systems::v0::Physics)?

That's a good point, those are definitely redundant. Ignition plugin won't find the correct interface unless it includes the `v0` and I'm not sure how easy it would be to also support dropping the `v0`.

Otherwise, if we remove the inline namespace from the systems themselves, the question is whether we expect users to be linking against the same system, but of different versions, at the same time. I can't think of a use case for this right now, but this kind of thing can be tricky to imagine beforehand.

> We can save this for Blueprint, but do we want to cmake-configure all of our SDF files to insert the current project major number?

Considering that we'll only be doing this whenever there's a new version, which isn't so often, I think we could just rely on search-and-replace. This is what we've been doing for  example cmake files in other Ignition libraries so far. Since all examples are build by tests, we'd catch the problem before merging a PR (not for world files though). I think this is a small price to pay to keep our files as close as possible to end-user code.
content.html:
Do we need a version number for both the library (e.g. the zero in libignition-gazebo0-physics-system.so) and in the interface (e.g. the v0 in ignition::gazebo::systems::v0::Physics)?

That's a good point, those are definitely redundant. Ignition plugin won't find the correct interface unless it includes the v0 and I'm not sure how easy it would be to also support dropping the v0.

Otherwise, if we remove the inline namespace from the systems themselves, the question is whether we expect users to be linking against the same system, but of different versions, at the same time. I can't think of a use case for this right now, but this kind of thing can be tricky to imagine beforehand.

We can save this for Blueprint, but do we want to cmake-configure all of our SDF files to insert the current project major number?

Considering that we'll only be doing this whenever there's a new version, which isn't so often, I think we could just rely on search-and-replace. This is what we've been doing for example cmake files in other Ignition libraries so far. Since all examples are build by tests, we'd catch the problem before merging a PR (not for world files though). I think this is a small price to pay to keep our files as close as possible to end-user code.

update.description:
For fun I tried bumping the version of gazebo to 1, and ran into some compile problems.

This PR should resolve the compile issues, however there is a run-time problem. All of our SDF files utilize version numbers when loading plugins. For example:

```
    <plugin
      filename="libignition-gazebo0-physics-system.so"
      name="ignition::gazebo::systems::v0::Physics">
    </plugin>
```

I have two questions:

1. Do we need a version number for both the library (e.g. the zero in `libignition-gazebo0-physics-system.so`) and in the interface (e.g. the `v0` in `ignition::gazebo::systems::v0::Physics`)? If not, can we get away with just the library version number? 

2. We can save this for Blueprint, but do we want to cmake-configure all of our SDF files to insert the current project major number? There are example and test SDF files to consider.
update.title: [WIP] Working on a version issue
